Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Story: I was finishing my shift as a lifeguard when I noticed a few pool chairs were out of place. They weren’t broken, just a little misaligned, but I knew part of my job was to keep everything tidy. As I started to straighten them, my phone buzzed. It was a message from my mom: “Rough day. Can you call when you have a minute?” I knew she’d been stressed lately, and I’d promised myself I’d check in more often, just to make sure everything was okay at home. I looked at the chairs, then at my phone, feeling the weight of both roles pressing on me. My supervisor expected the pool area to be perfect, but my parents needed me, too. I could hear my mom’s voice in my head, hoping for comfort, while also picturing my boss’s frown if the chairs weren’t fixed. My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between being the reliable son and the responsible lifeguard, not sure which expectation I should meet first.
